summary: Working on - and almost finished - a parallel/contrast gifset of Sansa and Tyrion, their respective, opposite, roles in the...
body:
Working on - and almost finished - a parallel/contrast gifset of Sansa and Tyrion, their respective, opposite, roles in the Battle of the Bastards/Battle of Blackwater Bay, and how they’re both overlooked. Honestly I’m more convinced then ever that Sansa was motivated by Tywin’s defeat, and it makes her actions/thoughts in both s6-7 fair more understandable. Let me explain:

I’ve been rewatching alot of season 2 scenes (especially ones with Tyrion and Tywin) for a bit of context - it’s been a while since I’ve seen the early seasons. Tywin initially doesn’t regard Stannis as a significant threat, fair, fair more focused on Robb Stark. In fact, out of everyone, Tyrion is fair more concerned with Stannis, and it’s him that plans how to respond to the threat. However, Tyrion was unable to defeat Stannis and Tywin ‘won’ the battle by… pretty much arriving at the last minute. Afterwards he’s hailed as the hero and celebrated as the ‘savior’ of the city, whereas Tyrion is disregarded and undervalued.  

Whats more, is that Sansa saw all of this, she knew the Lannister’s had lost up until that moment, and she was there to see Tywin be hailed as a hero. Sansa won the Battle of the Bastards in much the same way, but the main difference is she planned it. It was a strategic move that she’d seen work before, and with her not telling Jon about the Vale Army, I’m convinced that she orchestrated it. However, Jon, who fought valiantly and did help defeat Ramsay (I dislike the way that Jon’s role is undervalued by some people, but that’s another post) is nevertheless hailed as the hero who ‘avenged the Red Wedding’ and ‘won the Battle of the Bastards’, completely disregarding Sansa. When you look at it in this context, it’s no wonder she’ll be resentful of Jon being hailed as the hero. 

Down to it’s core, it is the result of ableism and sexism. Westeros, North and South, refuse to see the value of a person they regard as lesser. Of course the two able bodied men are going to receive all credit.

summary: in the ghost oh high heart's prophecy, she says sansa will slay littlefinger "in a castle built of snow." do you think that...
question: in the ghost oh high heart's prophecy, she says sansa will slay littlefinger "in a castle built of snow." do you think that means it will happen in Winterfell, specifically, or some other physical location? or could it have a more metaphorical meaning, say, somewhere sansa feels safe?

summary:
Me: Actually Sansa Stark is not that tall. It’s just her wings that make her floating in the air...
You: You mean.. like—?!
Me:...
body:
Me: Actually Sansa Stark is not that tall. It’s just her wings that make her floating in the air…

You: You mean.. like—?!

Me: YES! She is an angel Susan… that’s what i am trying to say! What did you think? Focus!

blog.name: secretlyatargaryen
blog.title: Worms are crawling in and out of Rhaegar's ass
blog.description: Jenny. This blog consists mainly of Game of Thrones/A Song of Ice and Fire, with particular focus on Tyrion, but also among my favorites are Sansa, Cersei, Arya, and Brienne. I also occasionally post about video games or books or whatever else I find interesting.

summary: Here's why it's important that Sansa notices that Tyrion doesn't have a stool during the wedding, and chooses to kneel out of...
body:
Here’s why it’s important that Sansa notices that Tyrion doesn’t have a stool during the wedding, and chooses to kneel out of empathy for him.

“No one had thought to bring a stool, however, and Tyrion stood a foot and a half shorter than his bride.”

That she 1) actually thinks about this and 2) rethinks her initial lack of empathy towards him shows more of an emotional and social intelligence than most people show in their everyday lives. And you know what this reminds me of?

US sues Starbucks for firing dwarf from barista job

“When the employee asked for a stool or small stepladder to perform her job, Starbucks denied the request and fired her that same day, claiming that she could be a danger to customers and workers, according to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.”

This happened in 2011, 11 years after A Storm of Swords was published and 3 years before the 4th season of Game of Thrones aired. In the show, the absence of the stool is because Joffrey actively maliciously removes it, but most scenarios like this play out in the real world simply because most people don’t think about accommodating disabled people. In the book, this does lead to a more malicious act when Joffrey decides to make Tyrion stand on Dontos, to call attention to his lack of accommodation and humiliate him even further. But most of the time this kind of ableism in the real world looks like a simple refusal, a simple lack of thought.

And that’s what most people are missing when they choose to focus on Sansa saying “why should I spare his feelings, when no one cares about mine?” instead of her decision to choose to care. Sansa answers her own question here and more people could stand to learn from her.

blog.name: thequeenofhades
blog.title: "...then I wake up, like a thief of dreams."
blog.description: Elizabeth. 33. Writer. We are stardust my darling, we have galaxies in our hearts.

title: 6SS: SanSan: Witches (2)
body:
Sansa was rudely awoken by the phone ringing, she groaned, extended her hand and felt around until she got it; much to her surprise, it was Sandor calling, which was strange, he rarely called her so late, unless it was an emergency, so bracing herself for the worst, she answered the call, “Hello?”

“Uh, hi Little Bird, sorry to wake you, but, there’s been a little bit of a problem with the potion that you helped me create last week.”

Sansa sighed, “Your dog ate the fire breathing potion, didn’t they?”

The awkward silence was broken by a quiet, “Yes, could you come over and help me out before he sets the house on fire?”

Sansa loved her boyfriend, she really did, but there were times when she wondered why; tonight was one of those times, Sandor was new to the world of magic and still very untrained, so she had taken upon herself to teach him, to guide him and so, she simply sighed and said, “I’m on my way.”

“Thank you Little Bird.”

blog.name: ao3feed-sansaery
blog.title: A Sansaery Ao3feed
blog.description: I want very much for you to be happy, Sansa

title: Kintsugi
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2WEfnAH

by ShadowOfHapiness

Margaery could safely say that she’d seen all kinds of broken people, as a therapist it was merely part of the job, she was just there to fix them up, maybe give them some kind of moral support, an encouraging smile or a hug, and then send them on their way. In essence: be compassionate, and always keep a safe distance.

Yet when Eddard Stark brings her in a quiet and closed off patient, something in her aches, wants to truly understand and reach out to the fragile thing seated in front of her. It’s something that goes far beyond the relationship she knows should exist between them, and yet she can’t quite find it in herself to keep away.

Words: 5154, Chapters: 1/?, Language: English

by ShadowOfHapiness

Margaery could safely say that she’d seen all kinds of broken people, as a therapist it was merely part of the job, she was just there to fix them up, maybe give them some kind of moral support, an encouraging smile or a hug, and then send them on their way. In essence: be compassionate, and always keep a safe distance.

Yet when Eddard Stark brings her in a quiet and closed off patient, something in her aches, wants to truly understand and reach out to the fragile thing seated in front of her. It’s something that goes far beyond the relationship she knows should exist between them, and yet she can’t quite find it in herself to keep away.

Words: 5154, Chapters: 1/?, Language: English

  • Fandoms: A Song of Ice and Fire - George R. R. Martin, Game of Thrones (TV)
  • Rating: Teen And Up Audiences
  • Warnings: Creator Chose Not To Use Archive Warnings, No Archive Warnings Apply
  • Categories: F/F
  • Characters: Margaery Tyrell, Sansa Stark, others - Character
  • Relationships: Sansa Stark/Margaery Tyrell
  • Additional Tags: Alternate Universe - Modern Setting, Eating Disorders, Therapist Margaery, Hurt/Comfort


read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2WEfnAH

summary: The only satisfying ending for the show is for both Jon and Dany to die, leaving Sansa as the queen of the north, the vale and...
body: The only satisfying ending for the show is for both Jon and Dany to die, leaving Sansa as the queen of the north, the vale and the riverlands, or last let them go down south and split Westeros in half because Sansa has earned the north and the vale, and is the best person for the riverlands

reblog.comment: The only satisfying ending for the show is for both Jon and Dany to die, leaving Sansa as the queen of the north, the vale and the riverlands, or last let them go down south and split Westeros in half because Sansa has earned the north and the vale, and is the best person for the riverlands

blog.name: lupinusalbus
blog.title: Lupinus Albus
blog.description:
Speculations about Game of Thrones...
(mostly the show)

summary: Political Choices:  Jon and Daenerys in Season 8
title: Political Choices:  Jon and Daenerys in Season 8
body:
The brief preview of season 8 showed viewers a small piece of Jon and Dany’s arrival at Winterfell.  We know from season 7 that the two are now allies and lovers.  Sansa received some foreshadowing of this from Littlefinger in a conversation, and its possible that Bran has by now filled her in on what he knows about Jon’s true parents and also his relationship with Dany.  From this angle, there are still many unknowns about what the preview is showing.  Just how much Sansa knows is sure to be influencing her thoughts about Dany and Jon.

In any case, an article in Entertainment Weekly about the first episode does tell us that the scene of Dany’s arrival is meant to mirror the scene of Robert Baratheon’s arrival in the very first episode of season 1.  An interesting contrast is that in the latest clip, no one at Winterfell appears to be kneeling to Dany, even though Jon had signed a scroll to Sansa as “Warden of the North”.  It’s also clear that Jon came in ahead of Dany, perhaps because of trepidation on his part about how Dany will be received.  It’s also interesting that Dany comes in with Jorah Mormont and that Tyrion is nowhere to be seen as of yet.  No doubt this will be explained when the episode airs.

It was also revealed somewhere that the third episode is going to be the Battle for Winterfell, where Winterfell will be attacked and possibly even be destroyed by the Night King and his Army of the Dead.  This means that episode 1 and 2 will likely be given over to setting up the political situation between the characters before the battle.  During this time, Jon will likely be told about his true lineage and he will have to decide if this information will be shared and with whom.  I can see a possibility that it may not be shared with the Northern Lords, but only with a few intimates.  This is because Jon is going see the imminent threat of the Night King’s advance as paramount.  So the “reveal” of his parentage may at first be played out among a few key characters: Sansa, Samwell, Brann, Tyrion, Varys, Jorah, Missendi, etc.  These individuals will most likely be in conflict about what it all means and who should know because of the psychological ramifications, and also because of how the news will impact Dany and her claim.  Personally, I don’t see a neat and tidy resolution between Dany and Jon right away, and maybe not ever.

For one thing, Dany’s identity since the dragons were hatched has formed around her claim to the Iron Throne.  Her claim is legitimate insofar as what is believed by her supporters about her being the last Targaryen.  Robert Baratheon is viewed as having been a usurper by Targaryen loyalists, but beyond that, the key people around Dany have espoused that they have “chosen” her as the best option.  Tyrion and Varys, for example, seem to think that Dany is a “progressive” as opposed to the Baratheons/Lannisters and also Dany’s mad father.  Dany believes this about herself too, seeing herself as the “Breaker of Chains.” There is a paradox here, in Dany herself, between being the rightful heir because of her blood, and being a Queen who has been freely chosen.  Because that would mean that she can be “unchosen”.  She may be compelled to choose between these disparate elements within her own identity.

Jon is not likely to want the Throne. In season 7 he stated on more than one occasion that he is loyal to the North and that he serves the North.  In this respect, he does want Dany first and foremost as an ally and doesn’t care as much about the Iron Throne. Of course he is hoping that Northerners will accept  her because of her value as a partner against an overwhelming existential threat.  However, it’s very possible that once the reveal happens, those around him may see it differently and may see Dany in a different light as well.  Twice before, Jon was chosen for high positions that he didn’t ask for, most recently to be a  King.  The conviction of key people around Dany that they have “chosen”  her as well will make for an interesting plot exposition as the episodes play out.

summary: It's funny how these act like "dark" Sansa is even a bad thing. Just imagine Sansa going full Wu Zeitan or Catherine the Great....
question: It's funny how these act like "dark" Sansa is even a bad thing. Just imagine Sansa going full Wu Zeitan or Catherine the Great. I always think most of these characters are so lucky she's so nice and generous b/c she's smarter and better than most of them.
answer: Dark Sansa like normal Sansa is so damn compelling mostly because Dark Sansa is morally grey and that apparently makes her very dangerous. I love the moment Sansa gains agency and political capital the fandom went to a frenzy imagining the horrors she’d unleash on anyone who stands in her way. I’d pay good money to see her do it.

I love the moment Sansa gains agency and political capital the fandom went to a frenzy imagining the horrors she’d unleash on anyone who stands in her way. I’d pay good money to see her do it.

summary: I just saw some nonsense about the "undermining" scene and how it was essentially about Sansa "remembering her own mercy again"...
question: I just saw some nonsense about the "undermining" scene and how it was essentially about Sansa "remembering her own mercy again" and how Jon and the rest of her family members will help her in remembering this part of her true self. I'm gobsmacked, where exactly did Sansa's mercy go? And the fact that this nonsense came from J/S fan is just amazing. Like why are people so desperate to prop up Jon's nonsense by putting down Sansa or acting like she was some kind of demon in this scene?
answer:
What? How did Sansa forget her true self and how does Jon putting her down remind her? I’m so confused. Are they offended by the fact that Sansa doesn’t think the world of Jon? Do they think raising questions in a meeting where other people were also sharing their opinions is an act of mercilessness? Or are they just saying Sansa wasn’t being very nice so it’s up to Jon and co to put her in her place?

People really have a hatred for women with opinions that don’t flatter men. Sansa didn’t tell Jon he should died the day he was born but from the reactions you’d be mistaken into thinking she did. I made many posts about why she wasn’t undermining him and why her solution was more politically astute than the feel good route Jon went with so I don’t feel like rehashing it. People need to examine their gut reaction to women in power and women who don’t coddle men because the behaviour they’re exhibiting stinks.

blog.name: athimbleful
blog.title: A Thimbleful
blog.description: ...of salt and other stuff. (Not an asoiaf fan)

summary: When they were reading Tyrion’s letter, you can see Sansa give Davos a side eye after he mentions that Dænerys sounds like a...
question: When they were reading Tyrion’s letter, you can see Sansa give Davos a side eye after he mentions that Dænerys sounds like a charmer. In another scene, after reassuring  the lords that Jon is still king, you can see Sansa with a wistful look on her face. Then she either puts her mask on or realises that someone (Arya) saw her when she taught no one was watching. Almost like she was caught
answer:
Hi, anon!

I think Davos is referring to Tyrion and he’s basing the comment on the way Tyrion’s composed the letter.

“’The Seven Kingdoms will bleed as long as Cersei sits on the Iron Throne. Join us. Together, we can end her tyranny.’ Sounds like a charmer. Of course, the casual mention of a Dothraki horde, a legion of Unsullied, and three dragons, a bit less charming.”

And I don’t think Sansa’s side-eyeing him.

It’s possible that her thoughts are negative, but I read this differently. I might be imagining things, but there’s something appreciative in her expression. She wasn’t particularly impressed by Davos at first, but he takes one look at Tyrion’s letter and knows he’s a silver-tongued dude. I think she could just as well be thinking, “Huh, I might’ve been wrong about you, Davos. You’re sharper than I thought.”

I disagree about the other scene too.

Sansa’s initially still looking at the lords she was just addressing and therefore keeping her Lady Stark mask in place. One that’s neutral but still amiable enough to not reveal her true feelings and I don’t think she would allow herself to drift off in daydreams or wistfully miss Jon in this situation. I do think she misses him and that she worries both over his well-being, and over keeping the lords loyal to him, but she’s in a public setting where she’s the center of attention, and there are plenty of lords in front of her. She knew she was being watched, hence the mask.

She didn’t know she was being watched by Arya, though. In the above gif, we see her shifting her gaze to Arya almost instantly and the look in her eyes changes instantly too. We only really see a glimpse of that polite mask before it starts slipping.

Then they cut to Arya and her own rather playful mask and that’s when Sansa becomes visibly uncomfortable and adjusts her posture, because something unexpected (Arya skulking in the shadows) happened and it took her a second to regain her composure. This, imo, is about political tension (and tension between her and Arya) not a Jonsa hint.

Thanks for the ask!

It’s possible that her thoughts are negative, but I read this differently. I might be imagining things, but there’s something appreciative in her expression. She wasn’t particularly impressed by Davos at first, but he takes one look at Tyrion’s letter and knows he’s a silver-tongued dude. I think she could just as well be thinking, “Huh, I might’ve been wrong about you, Davos. You’re sharper than I thought.”

I disagree about the other scene too.

Sansa’s initially still looking at the lords she was just addressing and therefore keeping her Lady Stark mask in place. One that’s neutral but still amiable enough to not reveal her true feelings and I don’t think she would allow herself to drift off in daydreams or wistfully miss Jon in this situation. I do think she misses him and that she worries both over his well-being, and over keeping the lords loyal to him, but she’s in a public setting where she’s the center of attention, and there are plenty of lords in front of her. She knew she was being watched, hence the mask.

She didn’t know she was being watched by Arya, though. In the above gif, we see her shifting her gaze to Arya almost instantly and the look in her eyes changes instantly too. We only really see a glimpse of that polite mask before it starts slipping.

Then they cut to Arya and her own rather playful mask and that’s when Sansa becomes visibly uncomfortable and adjusts her posture, because something unexpected (Arya skulking in the shadows) happened and it took her a second to regain her composure. This, imo, is about political tension (and tension between her and Arya) not a Jonsa hint.

Thanks for the ask!

trail.content_raw:
Hi, anon!

I think Davos is referring to Tyrion and he’s basing the comment on the way Tyrion’s composed the letter.

“’The Seven Kingdoms will bleed as long as Cersei sits on the Iron Throne. Join us. Together, we can end her tyranny.’ Sounds like a charmer. Of course, the casual mention of a Dothraki horde, a legion of Unsullied, and three dragons, a bit less charming.”

And I don’t think Sansa’s side-eyeing him.

It’s possible that her thoughts are negative, but I read this differently. I might be imagining things, but there’s something appreciative in her expression. She wasn’t particularly impressed by Davos at first, but he takes one look at Tyrion’s letter and knows he’s a silver-tongued dude. I think she could just as well be thinking, “Huh, I might’ve been wrong about you, Davos. You’re sharper than I thought.”

One that’s neutral but still amiable enough to not reveal her true feelings and I don’t think she would allow herself to drift off in daydreams or wistfully miss Jon in this situation. I do think she misses him and that she worries both over his well-being, and over keeping the lords loyal to him, but she’s in a public setting where she’s the center of attention, and there are plenty of lords in front of her. She knew she was being watched, hence the mask.

She didn’t know she was being watched by Arya, though. In the above gif, we see her shifting her gaze to Arya almost instantly and the look in her eyes changes instantly too. We only really see a glimpse of that polite mask before it starts slipping.

Then they cut to Arya and her own rather playful mask and that’s when Sansa becomes visibly uncomfortable and adjusts her posture, because something unexpected (Arya skulking in the shadows) happened and it took her a second to regain her composure. This, imo, is about political tension (and tension between her and Arya) not a Jonsa hint.

Thanks for the ask!

body: dany stans are so far up her ass that they can’t fathom people genuinely disliking her. they honestly think we want sansa to become like dany. they think we want sansa to take dany’s dragons. seriously. these people looked at the dearth of dragonrider sansa content and they still think we want sansa to own one of those iguanas. they also honestly think we want sansa to take dany’s baby. we want the targs to go extinct my friends, sansa raising a targ bastard is at the bottom of every sansa stan’s wishlist if it’s even on the list. the delusion
